'''''Tuber melanosporum''''', called the '''black truffle,''' '''Périgord truffle''' or '''French black truffle''',<ref>There are several common names for the species in the popular literature. For example, the ''Field Guide to North American Truffles'' (Trappe, Evans & Trappe, 2007) refers to it as the "French black"; ''Taming the Truffle'' (Hall, Brown, Zambonelli, 2007) calls it the "black Périgord truffle" (but lists it under the scientific name in the index); ''The Book of Fungi'' (Roberts & Evans, 2011) calls it the "black truffle"; and the European field guide ''Mushrooms'' (Laessoe & Lincoff, 2002) calls it simply the "Perigord truffle".</ref> is a species of [[truffle]] native to Southern Europe. It is one of the most expensive edible mushrooms in the world.

==Taxonomy==
Italian naturalist [[Carlo Vittadini]] described the black truffle in 1831.

==Description==

===External characteristics===
The round, dark brown fruiting bodies ([[ascocarp]]s) have a black-brown skin with small pyramidal cusps.<ref name="Gerhardt2011">{{cite book | isbn = 978-3-8354-0644-5 | title = Der große BLV-Pilzführer für unterwegs | last1 = Gerhardt | first1 = Ewald | year = 2011 | location = Munich | page = 662  }}</ref> They have a strong, aromatic smell and normally reach a size of up to {{convert|10|cm|in|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Laux2010">{{cite book | isbn = 978-3-440-12408-6 | title = Der große Kosmos-Pilzführer. Alle Speisepilze mit ihren giftigen Doppelgängern | last1 = Laux | first1 = Hans E. | year = 2010 | publisher = Kosmos | location = Stuttgart | page = 688  }}</ref> Some may be significantly larger, such as a black truffle found 2012 in [[Dordogne]] with a mass of {{convert|1.277|kg|lb|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite news|title=1,3 Kilo schwerer Trüffel in Dordogne gefunden|url=http://news.orf.at/stories/2099674/|accessdate=27 July 2013|newspaper=[[ORF (broadcaster)|ORF]]|date=15 January 2012}}</ref>

Their flesh is initially white, then dark. It is permeated by white veins which turn brown with age.<ref name="Cetto1988b">{{cite book | isbn = 978-3-405-13477-8 | title = Täublinge, Milchlinge, Boviste, Morcheln, Becherlinge u.a | last1 = Cetto | first1 = Bruno | year = 1988 | publisher = BLV | location = Munich | work = Enzyklopädie der Pilze | volume = 4 | page = 477  }}</ref> The spores are elliptical and measure about 22–55 [[µm]] by 20–35 µm.<ref name="Laux2010" /> They are dark brown and covered with large spikes.

=== Aroma ===
The fruiting bodies of the black truffle exude a scent reminiscent of undergrowth, strawberries, wet earth or dried fruit with a hint of [[Cocoa bean|cocoa]]. Their taste, which fully develops after the truffles are heated, is slightly peppery and bitter.<ref name="Bellesia">{{citation|surname1=Franco Bellesia|surname2=Adriano Pinetti|surname3=Alberto Bianchi|surname4=Bruno Tirillini|periodical=Flavour and Fragrance Journal|title=The volatile organic compounds of black truffle (Tuber melanosporum Vitt.) from Middle Italy |volume=13|issue=1|pages=56–58|date=  1998|language=German|doi=10.1002/(SICI)1099-1026(199801/02)13:1<56::AID-FFJ692>3.0.CO;2-X}}</ref> If stored at room temperature, the aromatic compounds dissipate, while storage at around the freezing point (0 °C) leads to an increased synthesis of these compounds.

The volatile compounds that contribute to the aroma and are developed by the fruiting bodies include [[2-methyl-1-butanol]], [[isoamyl alcohol]], [[2-methylbutyraldehyde]] and [[3-methylbutyraldehyde]], as well as traces of sulfur compounds.<ref name="Bellesia"/><ref>{{citation|surname1=Laura Culleré|surname2=Vicente Ferreira|surname3=Berenger Chevret|surname4=María E. Venturini|surname5=Ana C. Sánchez-Gimeno|surname6=Domingo Blanco|periodical=Food Chemistry|title=Characterisation of aroma active compounds in black truffles (Tuber melanosporum) and summer truffles (Tuber aestivum) by gas chromatography–olfactometry |volume=122|issue=1|pages=300–306|date=  2010|language=German|doi=10.1016/j.foodchem.2010.02.024}}</ref> One of these, [[dimethyl sulfide]], is what attracts truffle dogs, [[truffle hog]]s and truffle flies to the fruiting bodies.<ref>{{citation|surname1=T. Talou|surname2=A. Gaset|surname3=M. Delmas|surname4=M. Kulifaj|surname5=C. Montant|periodical=Mycological Research|title=Dimethyl sulphide: the secret for black truffle hunting by animals? |volume=94|issue=2|pages=277–278|date=  1990|language=German|doi=10.1016/S0953-7562(09)80630-8}}</ref> Several species of [[yeast]], which produce part of the aromatic compounds, have been isolated from ''Tuber melanosporum'' and ''[[Tuber magnatum]]''.<ref>{{citation|surname1=Pietro Buzzini u. a.|periodical=Archives of Microbiology|title=Production of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) by yeasts isolated from the ascocarps of black (Tuber melanosporum Vitt.) and white (Tuber magnatum Pico) truffles |volume=184|issue=3|pages=187–193|date=  2005|language=German|doi=10.1007/s00203-005-0043-y|pmid=16187098}}</ref>

===Genome===
The [[genome]] of the black truffle was published in 2010.<ref>{{citation|surname1=Francis Martin u. a.|periodical=Nature|title=Périgord black truffle genome uncovers evolutionary origins and mechanisms of symbiosis |volume=464|issue=7291|pages=1033–1038|date=  2010|language=German|doi=10.1038/nature08867|pmid=20348908}}</ref> It contains 125 million [[base pair]]s. 58% of the genome consists of [[transposable element]]s, and the genome contains only 7500 identified protein-encoding [[gene]]s. During symbiosis, genes involved in the decomposition of plant [[cell wall]]s and [[lipid]]s are induced. This indicates that black truffles decompose the cell walls of their host plants at the beginning of the symbiosis.

==Identification==
[[File:Truffière des Grèzes 01.jpg|thumb|right|Black truffle, cut]]
The black truffle is morphologically very similar to the commercially less valuable Chinese truffle (''[[Tuber indicum]]''). To avoid fraud or misidentifications in commerce, a [[Restriction fragment length polymorphism|RFLP]] genetic test has been developed to distinguish the two species.<ref>{{citation|surname1=Francesco Paolocci|surname2=Andrea Rubini|surname3=Bruno Granetti|surname4=Sergio Arcioni|periodical=FEMS Microbiology Letters|title=Typing Tuber melanosporum and Chinese black truffle species by molecular markers |volume=153|issue=2|pages=255–260|date=  1997|language=German|doi=10.1111/j.1574-6968.1997.tb12582.x|pmid=9271850}}</ref> Externally, they can be distinguished by their skin, which is smoother and dark red or dark brown in the Chinese truffle. Two other similar truffle species are the summer truffle (''[[Tuber aestivum]]'') and the winter truffle (''[[Tuber brumale]]''), whose flesh is of a lighter color.

==Ecology==

===Development and phenology===
[[File:Beaumont - truffières.jpg|thumb|Black truffles suppress the growth of plants around their symbiont, creating the impression of a burnt area.]]
Black truffles grow at a depth of {{convert|5|cm|in|abbr=on}} to {{convert|50|cm|in|abbr=on}} as [[ectomycorrhiza]]e, preferably in loose calcareous soil,<ref name="Linde">{{citation|surname1=C. C. Linde|surname2=H. Selmes|periodical=Applied and Environmental Microbiology|title=Genetic Diversity and Mating Type Distribution of Tuber melanosporum and Their Significance to Truffle Cultivation in Artificially Planted Truffiéres in Australia |volume=78|issue=18|pages=6534–6539|date=  2012|language=German|doi=10.1128/AEM.01558-12|pmid=22773652|pmc=3426713}}</ref> close to the roots of their plant [[symbiont]]s. These include [[holm oak]]s, [[Quercus robur|French oaks]], [[hazel]], [[cherry]] and other [[deciduous trees]].<ref name="Laux2010" /> The symbiosis of holm oak saplings and black truffles has been shown to improve [[photosynthesis]] and root growth in the plant.<ref>{{citation|surname1=Andrea Nardinia|surname2=Sebastiano Salleo|surname3=Melvin T. Tyree|surname4=Moreno Vertovec|periodical=Annals of Forest Science|title=Influence of the ectomycorrhizas formed by Tuber melanosporum Vitt. on hydraulic conductance and water relations of Quercus ilex L. seedlings |volume=57|issue=4|pages=305–312|date=  2000|language=German|doi=10.1051/forest:2000121|url=https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-00883314/file/hal-00883314.pdf}}</ref>

Black truffles suppress the growth of plants around their symbiont, creating the impression of a burnt (''brûlé'') area around it. They do so by [[parasite|parasitizing]] the roots of other plants, which may lead to [[necrosis]] of the root bark and the death of the parasitized plant.<ref>{{citation|surname1=I. Plattner|surname2=I.R. Hall|periodical=Mycological Research|title=Parasitism of non-host plants by the mycorrhizal fungus Tuber melanosporum |volume=99|issue=11|pages=1367–1370|date=  1995|language=German|doi=10.1016/S0953-7562(09)81223-9}}</ref> Moreover, part of the scent emitted by the truffles may limit the growth of other plants through [[oxidative stress]].<ref>{{citation|surname1=Richard Splivallo|surname2=Mara Novero|surname3=Cinzia M Bertea|surname4=Simone Bossi|surname5=Paola Bonfante|periodical=The New Phytologist|title=Truffle volatiles inhibit growth and induce an oxidative burst in Arabidopsis thaliana |volume=175|issue=3|pages=417–424|date=  2007|language=German|doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2007.02141.x|pmid=17635217}}</ref>

The fruiting bodies develop from April to June, and are harvested from November to March.<ref name="lexikon.huettenhilfe">{{cite web|title=Schwarze Trüffel|url=http://lexikon.huettenhilfe.de/gemuese/schwarze-trueffel.html|website=Huettenhilfe.de|accessdate=27 July 2013}}</ref>

===Reproduction===
[[Boar]]s and the [[larva]]e of the truffle fly (''[[Suillia tuberiperda]]''), which eat the fruiting bodies, aid in the distribution of the species by excreting the indigestible spores. Their excrement likely also serves to fertilize the spores. Black truffles are sometimes found together with winter truffles, which aid the growth of black truffles in wet soils.<ref>{{citation|surname1=M. Mamoun|surname2=J. M. Olivier|periodical=Plant and Soil|title=Competition between Tuber melanosporum and other ectomycorrhizal fungi under two irrigation regimes |volume=149|issue=2|pages=211–218|date=  1993|language=German|doi=10.1007/BF00016611}}</ref>

Up until 2010, all truffle species were thought to be [[homothallic]], that is, capable of [[sexual reproduction]] from a single organism. Subsequent research indicated that black truffles are [[heterothallic]], that is, sexual reproduction requires contact between [[mycelium]] of different [[mating type]]s.<ref>{{citation|surname1=Andrea Rubini|surname2=Beatrice Belfiori|surname3=Claudia Riccioni|surname4=Sergio Arcioni|surname5=Francis Martin|surname6=Francesco Paolocci|periodical=New Phytologist|title=Tuber melanosporum: mating type distribution in a natural plantation and dynamics of strains of different mating types on the roots of nursery-inoculated host plants |volume=189|issue=3|pages=723–735|date=  2011|language=German|doi=10.1111/j.1469-8137.2010.03493.x|pmid=20964691}}</ref> If a tree is surrounded by mycelium of different mating types, eventually one type becomes predominant. This is relevant for the operation of truffle plantations: To improve production, planters must ensure that neighboring trees harbor mycelium of different mating types, such as by inoculating new saplings with mycelium of a particular type.

==Habitat and cultivation==
The natural [[habitat]] of the black truffle includes various regions in Spain, France, and Italy. These are presumably the areas where the host plants found refuge during the last Ice Age. {{Citation needed|date=February 2017}} In these areas, the search for black truffles and their cultivation is a tradition going back more than 200 years. There are large areas of natural forests where truffles are still collected manually in a traditional way. For example, the county of Alto Maestrazgo (province of Castellón, Spain) has an ideal ground with suitable conditions for cultivating truffles. Albocàsser, Atzaneta, Culla, or Morella are just some of the villages in this region where you can find black truffles in large amounts.<ref name="Slow Living Mediterráneo">{{Cite news|url=http://www.slowlivingmediterraneo.com/slow-food-truffle-season-spain/|title=Spanish Truffle Recipes: Slow Food and the Truffle Season in Spain|date=2017-02-09|work=Slow Living Mediterráneo|access-date=2017-06-13|language=en-GB}}</ref>

Nevertheless, this form of recollection is increasingly affected by climate change and since the years 2010 there has been a significant drop in productivity in naturally producing forests. In exchange, cultivated areas are increasingly popular and in central Spain, several thousands of hectares (the Mecca of the black truffle being in Soria, Teruel province in the Aragon region). Some experiments have also been conducted in burnt areas, with promising results, as legally there is no need to ask for a land-use change when planting truffles, as it can be considered (EU-28) as forest land.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Martinez de aragon|first1=Juan|last2=Fischer|first2=Christine|last3=Bonet|first3=Jose-Antonio|last4=olivera|first4=Antoni|last5=Oliach|first5=Daniel|last6=Colinas|first6=Carlos|title=Economically profitable post fire restoration with black truffle (Tuber melanosporum) producing plantations|journal=New Forests|date=2012|volume=43|issue=5–6|pages=615–630|doi=10.1007/s11056-012-9316-x}}</ref>

Black truffles are now also cultivated in Australia, New Zealand, Chile,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://santiagotimes.cl/first-exports-of-chilean-truffles-set-for-2013/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-01-04 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150105010417/http://santiagotimes.cl/first-exports-of-chilean-truffles-set-for-2013/ |archivedate=5 January 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> North America, South Africa,<ref name="Linde"/><ref name="News24">http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/kokstad-farmer-finds-first-black-truffle-of-season-20160614</ref> and Wales.<ref>http://www.int-res.com/abstracts/cr/v74/n1/p67-70/</ref> Cultivation involves the planting of, for example, hazel trees whose roots are inoculated with truffle mycelium. The first fruiting bodies can be harvested about four to ten years after planting the trees.<ref name=madrimasd>madrimasd. "New technique to grow black truffles." ScienceDaily, 23 Oct. 2012. Web. 5 Aug. 2013.</ref>

==Production==
France accounts for some 45% of the world production of black truffles, Spain for 35% and Italy for 20%. Smaller amounts are produced in Slovenia, Croatia, and the Australian states of Tasmania and Western Australia. In 2005, black truffles were found in [[Serbia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://arhiva.kurir-info.rs/arhiva/2005/novembar/28/V-17-28112005.shtml |title=KURIR |publisher=Arhiva.kurir-info.rs |date= |accessdate=16 June 2012}}</ref> About 80% of the French production comes from southeast France: upper [[Provence]] (''[[départements of France|départements]]'' of [[Vaucluse]] and [[Alpes-de-Haute-Provence]]), part of [[Dauphiné]] (''département'' of [[Drôme]]), and part of [[Languedoc]] (''département'' of [[Gard]]). 20% of the production comes from southwest France: [[Quercy]] (''département'' of [[Lot (département)|Lot]]) and [[Périgord]]. The largest truffle market in France (and probably also in the world) is at [[Richerenches]] in Vaucluse. The largest truffle market in southwest France is at [[Lalbenque]] in [[Quercy]]. These markets are busiest in the month of January, when the black truffles have their highest perfume.{{citation needed|date=July 2013}}

Production has considerably diminished during the 20th century, dropping to around 20 metric tonnes per year, with peaks at around 46 tonnes in the best years. By comparison, in 1937, France produced around 1,000 metric tonnes of black truffles.

The following table shows the production in the EU of Tuber melanosporum in Spain, France and Italy. Production data is in metric tons, and country weights in percentage, and comes from the Groupe Européen Truffe et Trufficulture, an association of the main producers in Europe.

As the data shows, France has been the main producer of black truffles in the last decade and a half, but is rapidly challenged by Spain, where regions have made use of the EU-funded [[Rural Development Programme]] (EARFD funding) to subsidise cultivated plantations.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bonet|first1=Jose-Antonio|last2=Fischer|first2=Christine|last3=Colinas|first3=Carlos|title=Cultivation of black truffle to promote reforestation and land-use stability|journal=Agronomy for Sustainable Development|date=2006|volume=26|issue=1|pages=69–76|ref=HAL Id: hal-00886320|url=https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-00886320/document|doi=10.1051/agro:2005059}}</ref> This is particularly visible in the [[Teruel]] province of the [[Aragón]] region where the black truffle represents the first and main economic activity (in GDP and employment). Especially since 2010-2011 when many plantations done under the last Rural Development Programme 2000-2006 came into production phase.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bonet|first1=Jose-Antonio|last2=Oliach|first2=Daniel|last3=Fischer|first3=Christine|last4=Martinez de Aragon|first4=Juan|last5=Colinas|first5=Carlos|title=Cultivation Methods of the Black Truffle, the Most Profitable Mediterranean Non-Wood Forest Product; A State of the Art Review|journal=Modelling, Valuing and Managing Mediterranean Forest Ecosystems for Non-Timber Goods and Services|date=2009|issue=57|pages=57–71}}</ref>

==Commerce and use==
With a price of about 1,000 to 2,000 euros per kilogram, black truffles are the second most expensive truffles after [[white truffle]]s, and one of the most sought after edible mushrooms in the world.<ref name="lexikon.huettenhilfe"/>

In cooking, black truffles are used to refine the taste of meat, fish, soups and [[risotto]]. Unlike white truffles, the aroma of black truffles does not diminish when they are heated, but becomes more intense.<ref>{{cite news|last=Jochim|first=Tobias|title=Trüffel|url=http://www.gourmetglobe.de/kochen/tipps-vom-sternekoch/884-sternekoch-tobias-jochim-so-bereitet-man-trueffel-richtig-zu.html|accessdate=27 July 2013|newspaper=Gourmetglobe.de}}</ref>

In Spain, where black truffles are often used in cooking, one truffle dish is known as blanched eggs, or huevos escaldados in Spanish.<ref name="Slow Living Mediterráneo"/>

== Physiology ==
Truffles contain the [[Endocannabinoids|endocannabinoid]] [[anandamide]] (AEA) and the major metabolic enzymes of the [[endocannabinoid system]] ECS. The anandamide content increases in the late stages of truffles’ development. Anandamide and ECS metabolic enzymes may have evolved earlier than [[Cannabinoid receptor|endocannabinoid-binding receptors]], and anandamide might be an ancient attractant to truffle-eating animals, which are well-equipped with endocannabinoid-binding receptors.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pacioni|first=Giovanni|last2=Rapino|first2=Cinzia|last3=Zarivi|first3=Osvaldo|last4=Falconi|first4=Anastasia|last5=Leonardi|first5=Marco|last6=Battista|first6=Natalia|last7=Colafarina|first7=Sabrina|last8=Sergi|first8=Manuel|last9=Bonfigli|first9=Antonella|date=2015-02-01|title=Truffles contain endocannabinoid metabolic enzymes and anandamide|journal=Phytochemistry|volume=110|pages=104–110|doi=10.1016/j.phytochem.2014.11.012|pmid=25433633}}</ref>
